PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Marriage Act 1961.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Because this Bill is substantially the same as the Bill introduced last year, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The principal purpose of this Bill is to give legislative effect in Australia to the Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages signed by Australia in July 1980. The Bill represents a significant step for Australia in that it is the first of the Hague Conventions Australia has signed and will be the first to which Australia has given effect.

In addition, the Bill proposes certain other amendments to the Marriage Act 1961 with which I will deal at a later stage. The Bill is, for the most part, substantially the same as that introduced last year.
The Hague Convention

For many years it has been recognised that marriage is such a fundamental and universal human institution that, wherever possible, a marriage celebrated in one country should be recognised as valid all over the world. Nevertheless, there are limits to the extent to which the policy of one country is acceptable in another. To reconcile these conflicting goals, a complex set of rules has developed in the common law, governing recognition of marriages involving parties whose domicile is not Australia, or marriage celebrated outside Australia.

In 1983 35% of all marriages taking place in Australia involved one party who had been born overseas. The common law rules as they now stand would refer the validity of those marriages where one party was still domiciled outside Australia, partly to the law of the domicile. If a marriage takes place overseas, it might be necessary to refer to the law of a number of countries to determine its validity in Australia. The Hague Conference on Private International Law in 1976 finalised the Convention on the Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages ('the Hague Convention') to facilitate the recognition in one country of marriages solemnised in another country.
Celebration of Marriages

Chapter I of the Hague Convention deals with the celebration of marriages in countries party to the Convention. The Hague Convention requires a member country to allow the celebration of a marriage on its territory where the couple meet the requirements of the law of that country, provided that one of the parties is a citizen of that member country or habitually resides there.

At the moment Australian law forbids the marriage of parties in Australia where the law of the domicile of both of the parties forbids it. In practice, it is difficult for celebrants in Australia to form an opinion about the domicile of the parties or the law of a foreign country.

The Bill proposes to deal with this problem by recognising the position which, as a matter of practice, has existed in Australia for many years, namely, that marriage celebrants in Australia marry persons in Australia-whether or not they are foreigners-by reference only to Australian law.

To enable Australia to comply with Chapter I of the Hague Convention, the application of Part III of the Marriage Act-dealing with void marriages-is varied by clauses 10 to 13 of the Bill so that the rules of that Part will apply to all marriages solemnised after the amending provisions come into force in Australia or outside Australia under Australian law. This amounts to a variation of Australia's ''choice of law rules'' and means that each of the parties to a marriage will only be required to meet the requirements of Australian law before they may marry under that law.
Recognition of the Validity of Marriages

Chapter II of the Hague Convention imposes upon countries that are parties to the Convention an obligation to recognise marriages that are validly celebrated under the law of the place of celebration, subject to certain basic exceptions. This obligation will involve recognition being given to some marriages which would not be considered valid under the common law rules of private international law.

In implementing the Convention the Bill also provides, in new section 88E, that these common law rules will remain in operation to a limited extent, so that even if a marriage would not be recognised as valid under the Convention, it will nevertheless be recognised as valid if the common law rules so provide. Essentially, the Convention operates as a gloss upon the common law, as it will provide an additional basis upon which the recognition of validity of foreign marriages may be afforded.

The Convention rules are contained in a new Part (Part VA) to be inserted in the Act by clause 23. To give the maximum benefit, Part VA is to apply to all marriages whether solemnised before or after the Convention comes into force for Australia. The only difficulty that this may cause will arise where a party to a marriage, which was previously regarded as invalid, has remarried prior to the commencement of the new rules, relying on the invalidity of the prior marriage. Accordingly, there is a saving provision in new sub-section 88D (5) so that the first marriage in that situation will continue to be regarded as void, whether or not it would be valid under the Convention rules. Priority is thus given to the subsequent marriage, which was entered into in good faith.

Part VA will extend recognition to a marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia as valid throughout Australia if the marriage was, at the time it was solemnised, recognised as valid by the law of the country where it was solemnised or, alternatively, if the marriage is recognised as valid under that law at the time its validity falls to be determined (paragraphs 88C (1) (a) and (2) (a)). Analogous provisions will apply to marriages solemnised overseas by foreign diplomatic or consular officers.

These rules of recognition will, however, be subject to a number of exceptions, permitted by Article 11 of the Convention and set out in sub-sections 88D (2) and (3). A marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia will not be required to be recognised as valid under the Convention rules where:
either party was, at the time of the marriage, already married to some other person;
either party was not of the minimum Australian marriageable age, which is 16 years for males and 14 for females;
the parties were within a prohibited relationship; or
the consent of either was not a real consent.

Another provision of Part VA, section 88F, provides, in accordance with the policy expressed in Article 12 of the Hague Convention, that where the question of the validity of a marriage is incidental to the determination of another question (e.g. relating to inheritance) the validity question shall be resolved in accordance with the Convention rules. A prima facie method of proof of a marriage alleged to have been solemnised in a foreign country is also provided in section 88G.
The Bill also makes a number of other amendments.
Legitimacy of children
Some of these relate to Part VI of the Act, which deals with the legitimacy of children in certain circumstances.
One amendment, in clause 26, inserts new sub-section 93 (3) into the Act.

The background to this amendment can be found in the recent developments in technology to assist reproduction, most notably the technique of in vitro fertilization (IVF). This technique, together with the related one of artificial insemination by donor (AID), has given rise to discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General with a view to the enactment of uniform State and Territory legislation dealing with the parentage of these children. These discussions have not been concerned with the broader ethical and social issues raised by these techniques; they have simply been directed to the clarification of the status of the increasing number of children born in these ways. In general, the decision has been taken that a donor of genetic material should have no relationship with the child, and the legal parental relationship should be given to the 'social' parents.

In the context of Standing Committee discussions, some doubts were raised as to whether Part VI of the Marriage Act might not unintentionally frustrate part of this uniform law exercise. This would be so if the provisions of Part VI were to be interpreted by the courts as 'covering the field' with respect to the legitimation of children, leaving no room for the State laws concerned to have a valid operation.

The problem is a constitutional one to do with the overriding effect of Commonwealth law. This amendment will make clear the intention of the Parliament not to affect the validity or effect of State and Territory laws dealing with the parentage of these children.

The other amendment to Part VI, in clause 25, involves the extension of the operation of section 90 of the Act. That section deals with legitimation by virtue of a foreign marriage, and presently has no operation where the relevant foreign law does not recognise the status of illegitimacy. The amendment will deal with such a case by treating a child as legitimate if the parents subsequently marry.

The opportunity has also been taken to amend the application provisions of sections 89 and 90 so that they operate on the domicile of either parent, rather than only that of the child's father. This change reflects the situation in which a married woman now has a separate domicile, since the enactment of the Domicile Act 1982.
Notice of Intended Marriage

Minor amendments are made by clause 16 to section 42 of the Act to improve the operation of the provisions dealing with notices of intended marriage. The most important is the extension, from 3 months to 6 months, of the maximum period prior to the date of the marriage within which the notice can be filed. Extension of this time will allow celebrants and parties greater flexibility in making arrangements. The Family Law Council has considered this proposal, which has been put by civil celebrant groups, and sees no objection to it.

Australian diplomatic officials are added to the list of those who may witness a notice of intended marriage. This will make the necessary paperwork easier for those who have to come from outside Australia to marry in Australia.
Fees for Civil Celebrants

The Bill inserts provisions to provide that a civil marriage celebrant is not entitled to charge a fee for the solemnisation of a marriage higher than that prescribed by the regulations. This will make it clear that the prescribed fees are the legal maximum that can be demanded for solemnisation. It seems desirable, in light of the particularly vulnerable position of parties about to be married, that there be a clear legislative statement to this effect, for the protection of both parties and celebrants. It is not intended by this provision to affect the ability of celebrants to make reasonable charges for other matters ancillary to the actual solemnisation, such as flowers or music.

I should also point out that the Government is keeping under review the level of fees, to ensure, consistent with overall economic restraint, that the fees represent an adequate remuneration for this important service. Early last year the fees payable were significantly increased in light of these principles.
Provision of 'Marriage Education'

As a continuing part of the Government's response to recommendation 61 of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act-that 'education for marriage and family life be further supported'-the concept of 'Pre-Marital Education' in Part 1A of the Act is broadened to that of 'Marriage Education', by clauses 5 to 9. Organisations working in the area of pre-marital education have often indicated that one of the most useful times to engage in education for marriage is in that period shortly after the marriage has been entered into.

Recently this Parliament enacted long-needed changes to the laws governing the termination of marriage. This Bill represents another facet of the Government's commitment to resolving the problems faced by ordinary men and women in Australia in that most personal area of their lives. Particularly in extending the grounds for recognition of marriages entered into overseas, in ensuring the legitimacy of children recognised as such by State laws, and in broadening the scope of education for married life, this Bill is an affirmative statement of the importance of marriage as a fundamental and enduring institution.
The Bill has no financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

This matter was initially brought to the attention of the Senate by Senator Janine Haines. She referred the matter of the conduct of private hospitals and nursing homes in Australia to the Senate in September 1981 in response to increasing expressions of concern in the community about the ownership and operation of private hospitals and private nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, there were a number of areas of concern with respect to the nursing home industry. The standard of care received by nursing home patients had received considerable attention in the Press at that time. Many of the articles on nursing home patients painted a bleak and depressing picture of life in a nursing home and some articles raised serious allegations of ill treatment or lack of care. In addition, allegations that private nursing home proprietors were making excessive profits at the expense of patients had become common. The terms of reference before the Committee then covered essentially those main points.

I wish at this point to address one of the contentious parts of our report; that is, the use of the photographs of patients-very debilitated patients-suffering from decubitis ulcers, more commonly known as bed sores, from malnutrition and from general neglect. We did not include those photographs without a lot of thought and a lot of serious contemplation of the consequences. However, we felt that in view of the nature of the inquiry and the fact that there had been a number of such inquiries-it seemed so easy to sanitise problems of this nature simply in the black and white text of the report-it was high time that the Australian community was brought face to face with the consequences of neglect of elderly and vulnerable individuals receiving insufficient nursing and insufficient care and suffering from poor management of nursing homes and poor nutrition. We felt, though these patients represented a minority of those in nursing homes and though the poor care brought to our attention was being suffered in a minority of nursing homes, nonetheless the fact that it existed at all meant that the problem should be very forcibly brought to the attention of the Senate and the Australian public. The photographs that we used were presented to the Committee early in its deliberations. We took the precaution of checking with the sources of those photographs and were assured that we could be provided with an up to date set which would be just as compelling and evocative of the very problems that we wanted to emphasise.

I think the length of the inquiry needs to be explained to the Senate; over three years is possibly approaching a record for such an inquiry. We found that it was an extremely extensive reference, much wider than we had anticipated initially. We resolved as a result that there should be two separate reports to the Senate, the first of which we are now dealing with. In the interim we had a double dissolution, necessitating reappointment of the Committee, which in itself was the cause of a certain hiatus. In addition to that there was an enormous amount of change in the industry during those three years and we found that we were continually revising the text of our report.

I pay a very sincere tribute to the members of the Committee, which was led by Senator Walters in the role of Chairman during the first eighteen months of the inquiry. The enormous amount of effort and commitment that was put in by individual committee members had to be seen to be believed. I certainly express my gratitude to them for that commitment. We were served by two excellent secretariats-another cause for delay being the change in personnel in the middle of the inquiry. Initially our Secretary was Pat Mayberry and ultimately it was Tim Dodson. They, their research assistants and their stenographic support put in sterling work which, towards the end, was far beyond the call of duty. To them I extend the gratitude of the Committee.

In the course of the inquiry we received 161 submissions and interviewed 142 witnesses who represented 53 organisations. Towards the end of the inquiry-and this is another cause of the delay-we felt that we should open up our hearings again for further evidence in relation to the question of funding of nursing homes. We did this in view of the fact that we had become aware of a number of cases before various courts that had been brought by owners of nursing homes who felt that the fees they were permitted to charge were quite inadequate in terms of the viability of their nursing homes.

I would like to express my gratitude once again to all those people who made submissions and who appeared as witnesses before the inquiry. Many witnesses, to whom we have had to go back time and time again for further elucidations and to keep up with the changes that have been occurring within the industry co-operated wonderfully. We were also very fortunate in the latter stages of the report to have the services of Dr Anna Howe. Dr Howe, who is one of Australia's leading specialists in the care of the aged, was able to assist us to emphasise issues which were of particular significance in the report, having regard to the number of reports in this area that have gone before. The topic of aged care accommodation had already been examined by a sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. Other reports concerning care of the aged have been produced in the last decade, a number of which made recommendations with respect to nursing homes or the administration and funding of nursing home programs. Rather than merely repeat this information, our Committee has concentrated on those areas which have not been dealt with before or which the Committee believes deserve special consideration.

One of those issues was ownership of nursing homes. As I mentioned before, public statements have been made by a wide range of interested people on the possible conflict of interest which would occur in the event of doctors owning nursing homes to which they referred their own patients. We determined early in the course of the inquiry to conduct a survey of the ownership in the nursing home industry. I am happy to report that in the end, after a little while and, in some cases, after three or four letters were sent, the co-operation of the nursing home industry was excellent. Out of a total of 761 nursing homes surveyed, all but two were prepared to return to us their completed questionnaires in relation to the ownership of nursing homes. We were concerned, of course, about beneficial ownership. We were also concerned that company and trust ownership might confuse the issue and in many cases mask the actual ownership of nursing homes.

We discovered in our survey that in fact at that stage only 88 owners reported being medical practitioners and that of those, very few-in fact, six-reported referring patients to their own nursing homes. We found, however, that a total of 265 people with beneficial ownership reported their occupations as home duties and 400 reported their occupations as students. Unfortunately our questionnaire was not finely tuned enough to enable us to draw out from the statistics on beneficial ownership in respect of the families of medical practitioners.

At June 1984 the nursing home industry encompassed 1,448 nursing homes. This is the figure for the whole spectrum, including nursing homes run by State governments, those that are in the private enterprise sector and those that are run by religious and charitable organisations which are not, of course, operated for profit. Of that total of 1,448 nursing homes, 761 were run by private enterprise. The industry has a total of 75,000 beds Australia-wide. In 1983-84 the Commonwealth spent approximately $1,065m on accommodation and nursing home care for the aged. Of this amount, 92 per cent was spent on residential accommodation and care and only 8 per cent-that is, $88m-was spent on home care and domiciliary care services of which, of course, the aged are the major users.

Although these figures may sound quite enormous in relation to the amount spent generally on care of this nature in the Australian population, I would like to point out that only 7 per cent of those over the age of 70 is in any sort of supported accommodation or care. We had indications that in some States perhaps one in four of that 7 per cent of people over 70 years of age is in more heavily supported accommodation than is absolutely necessary. Over the years, however, as the nursing home industry itself has been developing very rapidly, as is clear from the figures, the provision of domiciliary care has been much less widespread and much less effective. It was clear from the evidence we received time and time again that very many people would be able to stay in their own homes or would be very well accommodated in less heavily supported care if such facilities were available.

The recommendations of the Committee went to a number of these and other issues. If I may, I would like briefly to summarise those recommendations because I know that many honourable senators take a very close interest in these issues, as indeed they should. We have suggested amongst our recommendations that the growth of the nursing home industry be more strictly controlled than has been the case in the past. Over the last 22 years there has been an increase from 27.4 beds per thousand of the population over 65 years of age to 47.5 beds. We felt that the rate of the increase, which certainly has slowed down over the last few years, should be much more severely controlled. We have recommended a maximum one-third increase of current nursing home beds in the period to June 30 1996.

It is quite obvious that not only is the actual number of nursing home beds in Australia of great significance but it is also significant that their distribution is very uneven both in a geographical sense and a socio-economic sense. We have suggested that priority be given to providing nursing home accommodation in areas where the existing provision of beds is below 60 beds per thousand persons aged 70 years and over and that, in order to reduce the number of beds in areas of oversupply-all of us are aware of suburbs in our own cities where there are nursing homes in every other street-the Commonwealth Department of Health, after consultation with the States, consider a number of options, none of which would be particularly draconian. Firstly, it might be possible to persuade charitable and religious groups progressively to convert their nursing homes to a range of appropriate aged persons' accommodation such as hostels. It may also be possible for the Commonwealth to purchase nursing homes as they come on to the market in areas of oversupply and use them for other health or welfare purposes.

We are particularly concerned that nursing home accommodation be appropriate to the geographical areas in which it is developed. We were told, for example, of three private nursing homes built fairly recently in the local authority area of Sunshine in Victoria. All of those three private nursing homes were priced out of the reach of the majority of people living in that area. We have suggested that the basis on which the funding of nursing homes is determined be changed from a per capita basis to a program grant basis. We have also suggested that until this happens some of the financial problems experienced by a significant sector of nursing homes would be solved by the determination of nursing home benefits twice yearly rather than annually as is presently the case. We feel that if this were done twice yearly in tandem with pension increases it would be a great deal more equitable as far as some nursing home owners are concerned. Certainly, there are people in the industry who are struggling to remain viable.

We are concerned that many of the deficit funded nursing homes are not providing the assistance which it was intended initially should be provided through these homes to people in greatest need. We have made a suggestion that the Commonwealth Department of Health, while acknowledging the prior rights of persons who have contractual arrangements through their hostel accommodation and so forth, ensure that the highest possible proportion of beds in deficit funded homes be made available to those in greatest need. Once again, we draw attention to the fact that many of the deficit funded homes have been established in fairly high socio-economic areas, which is not particularly appropriate to achieving accommodation for the less affluent. We would like to see government priority for the provision of capital subsidies for nursing homes, under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act, redirected towards the provision of other forms of accommodation. This would be in line with our recommendation that there be a ceiling on the number of new nursing home beds made available within the next 10 or 12 years.

We are particularly concerned about the inequities which have occurred in the benefits paid to the States by the Commonwealth, which have an historic basis in the enormous difference in staffing levels between nursing homes in the various States. We have suggested that the Commonwealth set its own staffing levels, taking into account the different needs of patients, and that where States want nursing hours above the level set by the Commonwealth the States themselves be responsible for the extra expense involved.

Our recommendations in relation to program grants, to which I referred earlier, would be to overcome the incentive that currently exists for nursing homes to keep all their beds occupied at all times. Our move, quite recently, to provide respite beds in nursing homes and in hostels was, I believe, a first step in that direction.

It was put to us a number of times during the inquiry that it was perfectly logical, reasonable and desirable for a nursing home to be able to put to the Commonwealth Government a program which would be appropriate to the social needs of its own geographical area and to the needs of the individuals in that area. We believe this is the way in which the industry should be encouraged to develop. I imagine that we will see a considerable amount of experimentation over structures-I hasten to assure honourable senators that that will not apply to patients-over the next few years. For example, a nursing home may wish to provide accommodation for a high proportion of patients suffering from Alzheimer's disease; that is, those with senile dementia. This would mean extra staff and specially designed facilities. The extra cost could be built into the program grant and the extra facilities, the extra staff and services generally, could be provided for within that grant. We would like to see that introduced as soon as possible. It is a highly complicated process, but a fair amount of work has been done already. We would advocate that an independent review be undertaken three years after the implementation of such a program.

We have advocated also that, as an interim measure only, for nursing homes established before 1973 or any other home with extremely low profits the Commonwealth allow a level of profit sufficient to ensure the viability of these homes until the system of program grants is implemented. Repeatedly evidence was given to the Committee that some nursing homes showed a very low level of profit. This evidence was substantiated by a survey done by Price Waterhouse Associates Pty in 1981. To the extent that it is desirable to keep private nursing homes functioning-certainly those with good and sustainable standards-the Committee agreed that a margin for profit must be included in the determination of fees.

Regarding the ownership of private nursing homes, there were dissenting opinions within the Committee. The majority view was that all States-of course this is not a matter on which the Commonwealth can legislate-should pass legislation prohibiting doctors from admitting patients to nursing homes in which they have a notifiable interest, which is defined clearly among the recommendations. Time and again we were faced with evidence of the potential for conflict of interest. As I have said, our survey of ownership showed up an apparently very minor element of potential conflict of interest, but while that potential is there it is felt by many people who gave evidence and by a majority of the members of the Committee that that conflict of interest should be clearly avoided by the simple expedient of prohibiting doctors from admitting patients to nursing homes in which they or their families have a notifiable interest. That was not the most draconian approach we could have taken. We could have recommended to the States that doctors should not be permitted to have financial interests in nursing homes. We did not go quite as far as that but, the Committee felt that the more moderate recommendation was justified.

We spent a lot of time concerning ourselves with the standard of care in nursing homes. This issue has received a great deal of attention in the Press at one time or another and the most horrifying examples have been described on a number of occasions. It is absolutely true to say that there is no national code of physical standards for nursing homes and certainly there is no national standard of care within nursing homes. We felt it absolutely crucial that the Commonwealth Department of Health work towards introducing codes on these two matters as soon as possible. We advocated too that an inspectorate section be set up within the standards and development branch of the central office of the Commonwealth Department of Health, with regional sections situated in each State's regional office. The current state of affairs in relation to the inspection of nursing homes is totally unsatisfactory. This is spread across the responsibilities of local, State and Commonwealth authorities. Even where those authorities are doing their job efficiently according to their own guidelines and regulations, the sum total is certainly not an effective control of standards within nursing homes in Australia.

I hasten to interpolate once again that we visited nursing homes in all the States-we saw some of the best, some of the mediocre and some of the very bad-and found that the majority are providing an honest service to their patients within the constraints of the systems that currently exist. Some nursing homes are providing an excellent service, but far too many are in a state of confusion about exactly what constitutes a high standard of care.

I think all honourable senators would agree that we have a moral obligation to make certain that the vulnerable and frail aged are cared for as well as possible and that we have a wider responsibility to the whole community to ensure that this happens. In view of the fact that well over $1m is being spent each year in this sector, we also have an obligation to the public purse.

For nursing homes which were persistently poor and refused to lift their standards in response to complaints and repeated inspections, we chose the solution first advocated by the inquiry by Price Waterhouse Associates, which was that there should be a hit squad-to describe it loosely-comprising a geriatrician, a senior nurse, a hygenist, a dietitian, an accountant, an industrial officer and a tax inspector, which would move in, seal off the nursing home and inspect it thoroughly from top to bottom, back to front and inside out and that the inspection by this team be held without notice and completed in one visit.

To deal with complaints about care of the aged we need to set up an authority independent of the departments which have been closely involved in the delivery of these programs. Our suggestion is that a separate complaints office be established. As we are not dealing solely with Commonwealth programs conducted by Commonwealth employees, the Ombudsman or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is not the appropriate body for the carriage of such aged care complaints. We believe such an office would need to be established by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) somewhat along the lines of the Human Rights Commission. It would provide for conciliation between the parties which, in many cases, we feel would lead to a resolution of complaints. The office must be backed by legislation in the event of more drastic action having to be taken, which we believe would happen very rarely.

I emphasise once again that a comparatively small section of the Australian population is in need of care in nursing homes. The majority of the people currently in nursing homes are being well cared for but there must be more emphasis placed on the care that people, when given the opportunity, wish to have within their own homes. Within the next few years, I feel certain, there will be a great deal of movement towards the implementation of the recommendations we are making. I believe these not only will increase the quality of care that is available but also will ensure that the care is being directed to those who need it most; that each individual receives the most appropriate care, and that the Commonwealth together with the States fully accepts its responsibility to the frail and the elderly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to make some remarks about the report of the Senate Select Committee into Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. I preface those remarks by thanking officially the Chairman, Senator Giles. I can say with a particular understanding that Senator Giles on occasions had to deal with some difficulties that arose-very nice difficulties-and she managed them with her particular skill and ability. I joined the Select Committee in 1983 and found myself on, I think, the first all-women Senate committee. At that stage, as Senator Giles has elaborated, the Committee was well under way, so I appreciated that I was not part of the Committee from its beginning. I formally thank the Chairman, both on my behalf and on behalf of the other members of the Committee, for the extraordinary job she has done in chairing this Committee since I have been a member of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The points that Senator Giles raised need to be noted. They are that from time to time, when we thought we were ready to write our report and present our recommendations, it suddenly became obvious that we would have to rehear evidence or take into consideration changes in the industry or, as Senator Giles mentioned, reconsider some of the cases brought before courts concerning complaints involving private nursing homes. From time to time we were about to make our report and we found that we just had to start again. Patience was needed by our Chairman in getting us through those difficulties.

I thank my colleagues and I join Senator Giles in thanking the support staff. The Secretariat worked splendidly. Quite often after we had retired wearily at the end of a long day the Secretariat continued to work. Behind the Secretariat was the back-up staff on the word processors and the stenographers who may have kept even longer hours in order to finalise the report. I think it is important to acknowledge them and I thank them in particular.

One of the reasons why I am very appreciative of this report is that if at any time I want to find out about the private nursing home industry I can look up the report. I found it an extraordinary challenge to master the whole range of complexities concerning money, legislation and regulations and the various sub-sections under the heading of the private nursing home industry. I am very grateful to have a report which contains not only recommendations about those difficulties but also much data collected in one place. Anyone looking at it will see that it is a huge report. It is larger than many I have seen tabled in the last couple of years. I do not have too long a history in the Senate, and perhaps there are many reports which are larger, but this report seems to me to be very comprehensive. It has to be as that is the nature of the industry and the nature of what we found out as we went through the inquiry. This is only half of the report, so it is an extraordinary reference to which we have addressed ourselves. The report does address all the complexities that I think have been outlined so adequately and pertinently by Senator Giles. I do not wish to run over those points again.

During the hearing of the evidence I learnt just how confusing and how complex the private nursing home industry is. There are huge numbers of variations contingent on special nursing homes, special requests, special numbers of beds, special nursing requirements and so on, and they have added to the complexity. I think the report is very timely. I understand the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is going to examine this report thoroughly because the private nursing home industry is a matter of great concern to the Government, particularly because of the cost to the public purse of expenditure in this industry.

I would like to raise a couple of points before I return to the minority reports. Senator Giles alluded, towards the end of her report, to the care of patients, which we paid particular attention to in the course of our examination. The priority concern for all of us when we examine the private nursing home industry is the quality of care for the patients. I am sure we have no dispute about that. It is not a matter of profit, of nursing regulations or of how the buildings look; it is a matter of what is provided in terms of care for those patients who, mostly for medical reasons and sometimes for medico-social reasons, finish up living part of or the end of their lives in such nursing homes. It is the quality of care, and much of the report attended to that. Like every other section of this report, it turned out to be a sort of Pandora's box. The more we looked at it, the more we found we had to look at and the more complex it became.

There are difficulties in defining what is meant by care. Are we talking about nursing care, something more extensive than nursing care or something more restrictive than nursing care? If we describe nursing care, we have to describe the personnel who will provide it. The Committee attempted to address all of those variations and areas of the definition of the providers of service or care. It is easy enough to say that finding a good quality nursing home with good quality nursing care will fix the problem. But our Committee actually had to define what it meant by a good quality nursing home and good quality nursing care. It turned out to be a very difficult task and a very extensive number of hours were devoted to it. I think we have taken some considerable steps towards the final definition that will probably be necessary in that area.

There are difficulties in terms of defining what is necessary for a patient. There are also difficulties in defining what is necessarily called nursing duties for the staff. In providing good quality care we have to make sure that we have satisfied or happy providers of the care. The problem in the nursing industry has been not only a matter of buildings but also a matter of staffing and definitions of duties for the staff in those nursing homes. Again we became very aware of how difficult it is to define exactly what is a nursing duty, although some of the nursing unions-in particular, the Royal Australian Nursing Federation-have moved some considerable distance in making those definitions. The Committee was able to draw on their already established definitions. Some very extensive research also has been done and that was a help for the Committee too. But I think there will still be room for further definition, further exactness and perhaps further flexibility in how those definitions go.

Then the consideration extended to the assistant staff, domiciliary staff, caretaker staff and backup support staff and to where their duties finish and where nursing duties start, or vice versa. Again, the Committee spent some time deliberating on these matters and made recommendations in that area. But I imagine that they will be open to continuing consideration. I also comment that one of the things I learnt during my time on this Committee was that if there is any area where history seems to be happening by the day or the week it is the nursing home industry. There have been great changes in this whole area since the late 1950s and early 1960s. There has been a huge increase in the number of beds. Although, as Senator Giles commented, the rate of increase is slowing down now, the expectation of the use of such beds will continue certainly until the turn of the century and possibly even beyond that-perhaps until the year 2010 when it is projected that our aged population will be dramatically increasing as a percentage of those not yet aged.

So we cannot see any likelihood that the number of nursing home beds will lessen. But we can see a change in requirements for who shall go into nursing home beds, how those nursing home beds are allocated and where they are distributed. Considerations such as whether respite care use of nursing home beds should be increased, whether a section of every nursing home should be set aside for respite care and the distribution of respite care beds across a State or an area illustrate just some of the questions we can ask, did ask and did address. I say in summary that my learning on this Committee has come from looking at an industry or an area of our society that is very much in a process of change. I think it will continue to change and that we need to have in place a system that will allow evaluation of that process as it is happening so that we, government, professions and the industry itself can adjust as necessary, depending on the requirements and the consequences of those changes.

I turn now to the minority reports. I think one of the points which again Senator Giles touched on was the coloured photographs that we included in our report. This was raised as a difficulty in one of the dissenting reports. I very strongly endorse the inclusion of those photographs. Again I think it is important for us to make sure that it is understood that we were talking about a very bad, very small part of this comprehensive industry. But I do not believe that our society ought not know of or be protected from some of the really quite horrific things that happen in very few of the nursing homes. It is far better that those things are known and prevented. Such nursing homes should be closed or not allowed to practice in that way, so that elderly people in our society are protected from that kind of gross, dehumanising mismanagement.

So yes, these things do make us draw breath, but they remind us that, in this society of Australia which is so wealthy, so affluent, so beautiful and so caring, such things as poverty and appalling medical care do happen. If we claim to be as good as we sometimes do, I think we must make sure that no small exceptions like that happen. It was claimed in the dissenting report that reporting those stories would get a bad name for the whole industry. I think the situation is no different from any other regulation in any other industry in that when the bad parts are highlighted people can be sure that the part of the industry that remains is more credible because it is quite clear that it is not associated with the very bad service in a few parts of the industry. Besides, I think we should never flinch from making those sorts of facts known, even if it is necessary to change the whole profession or the whole industry. In this case it was a very small change. There were not many hospitals and nursing homes that gave that kind of appalling care.

The other point that I think is important is the conflict of interest. I must say that I would not have been troubled to support the even tougher proposal that doctors not be allowed to own any interest in nursing homes. I think that in the history of this whole industry many medical people with wisdom and care of patients as their principal concern have established nursing homes or helped to contribute to the establishment of nursing homes precisely to provide that sort of assistance and care which they knew, from knowing their patients, was necessary. I have no conflict with that. I think the medical profession can hold its head high in terms of the many wonderful initiatives it has led for the benefit of people in this country.

But we come to a time when we have to look hard at the possibility of a conflict of interest in this area. It is not unlike, I think, the doctors and the pharmacists who, some time ago, for the benefit of their patients, were arranging to provide their services close by. It was quite obvious after a while that there was a possibility of conflict of interest. In fact, I suspect that there was some evidence to that effect. I think it is a case of realising the potential and preventing it. As Senator Giles has said, we have also had some hint of evidence that it is already a possibility in this country. I do not believe that we should discredit the profession or allow anything that might discredit the profession. Nor should we allow anything that might lower the possibility of good quality care for patients. So I do not see that it is impossible to require by legislation that doctors not be allowed to own an interest in nursing home beds. However, the Committee did not make that recommendation to that extent. It simply recommended that doctors not be allowed to refer patients to nursing homes in which they have a financial interest. What is meant by a financial interest of the doctor is very clearly defined in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is not this a moral question? You really cannot secure it with legal sanctions. It is a question of moral approach by doctors. You cannot secure it legally.
—Sadly, I think we have evidence that from time to time even the medical profession is less than 100 per cent moral.
—So is everyone.

—Indeed. I would have thought that, as we now have it clearly from the lips of the honourable senator on the other side of the chamber that everyone is not always 100 per cent moral, we can include the suggestion that the doctors are not 100 per cent moral and have his support in this matter. We know that is so, therefore I think we have a responsibility to address the possibility of conflict of interest. Most doctors do not have that conflict, although some do. We had evidence before the Committee indicating that such a conflict was quite likely to happen-that the potential was there-and that it has happened. Therefore, I believe that it is no hardship and no great matter to change circumstances so that this conflict of interest is not possible.
—It still remains possible.

—I do not believe it is an amazing statement. As we have evidence that doctors are open to that kind of conflict of interest we should ensure that it is not possible. Of course our principal reason for doing that is that we are looking at continuing respect for the profession and continuing the quality of care of patients. As I said in the beginning, I think that is our priority concern. We must provide people with the sort of medical and humane care that will make their time in a nursing home-if such time is necessary-compatible with humanity and compassion. We should not allow the moving of people in and out of nursing homes merely because it increases the nursing home's profit. That does not help patients. Moving patients is against their good care, particularly the elderly who may be approaching senility or who cannot care for themselves because they are no longer clear in their minds. I am interested that there is an objection to this recommendation. As Senator Giles said, we were certainly far less harsh and far less direct and comprehensive than we could have been. We settled for a moderate half-way approach which simply states that doctors may not refer patients to a nursing home in which they have a financial interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The dissenting report recommended instead that medical practitioners with such a financial interest be required to notify the patients in writing of that interest. I suggest that to write to many of these elderly confused patients informing them of a financial interest in a nursing home may cause only further confusion or possibly even fear or fright. I think that is an unsatisfactory way of dealing with a possible conflict of interest. Also, I think it makes patients the deciders as to whether the doctor is in a potential conflict of interest situation. I do not believe that any elderly or ill patient requiring nursing home care ought to be the person to make that decision. I think in some way that is a classic example of an abdication of responsibility. As we have evidence that the medical profession is not 100 per cent honourable, I think this requires that the Government unashamedly ensure that the possibly does not arise. Of course, in that way the proposed recommendation in the dissenting report would not come into effect and indeed would not be necessary because patients would be protected from having to decide whether they might be putting their doctors in a potential conflict of interest situation.

The second dissenting report sees the need for the Government to make some recommendation about the numbers of nursing home beds and suggests an attempt at fairness in the distribution of nursing home beds. However, the dissenting report comments that changes to the 35-day hospital occupancy rule could make such a change in the requirement for nursing home beds that proper or responsible planning will not actually be effected. As I understand the dissenting report, it is being suggested that as from time to time things may be very difficult, we should not do it in the first place. I think that is an insufficient argument to mount against our majority recommendations. I think it is more important to say that we unashamedly support the idea of responsible government planning in terms of the distribution and number of nursing home beds, particularly in regard to the number of dollars involved in the nursing home industry. I think it is important that from time to time, with changes that may affect nursing home bed occupancy, those matters be considered and taken into account-not in terms of not having planning in the first place but in consideration of the proposed changes being introduced. I do not find myself persuaded by the argument put forward in that dissenting report. I support the majority report.

I differ with the dissenting report as to how we address what is an honourable return on investment in a nursing home. There are numbers of points raised in the dissenting report as to whether goodwill should be included in the valuation of the nursing home-particularly at a time of sale. The Committee appreciates that this has been a matter of considerable difficulty and that it remains a difficulty for the industry. In fact I think it could be said that it is an area that still needs to be addressed comprehensively and, presumably, by both the Government and the industry.

However, it is true to say also that when a nursing home is built and a person occupies a bed that automatically guarantees a considerable number of government dollars, as part payment of the cost of that bed, to the nursing home. That is not a situation which is matched in almost any other industry in this country. Goodwill, which is really very much a government contribution as well as a good name notion, needs to be taken into account when looking at the sale of such a nursing home and when looking at the whole pricing and fee structure in that area. I also disagree with the dissenting report in respect of requirements by the Committee on the display of nursing home ownership. Much of the evidence taken by the Committee addressed the question of who owned nursing homes. We discovered it was very difficult to know who owned a nursing home. Very often company names were involved. The names of some members of the medical profession or relatives of medical professionals, or the names of sub-companies of other companies, were involved. To find out who actually were the owners of a nursing home was a considerable hunt and chase task. The Committee felt that it was very important the ownership of nursing homes be displayed in some easy way so that people coming into that nursing home, particularly people visiting or people looking to be admitted to such a nursing home, would have the option of reading a list of owners and knowing who they were.

In some way it is a disappointment that a committee should have to make a recommendation such as that. It highlights two things: One is the difficulty of knowing who has owned nursing homes in the past; the other is the possibility of conflict of interest which I referred to before. I think it would be part of a general increase in information giving people a better opportunity to make decisions. Sometimes people are not sure who owns a nursing home. Sometimes it is said: 'I thought it was a charitable nursing home or a home owned by so and so'. We feel it is a matter of importance that the ownership of nursing homes be clearly displayed so that kind of confusion is less possible. However, I presume there is always a possibility for some confusion.

I finish my comments by alluding to the comprehensive nature of this report in its analysis of the nursing home industry. As I said earlier, I am delighted to have the report because I do not now have to hold all the information in my memory; I can look it up in the report. I think it is important that we have discovered just how extensive and complex the whole industry is. Again, I think it is important to say that with the focus of the quality of care as our priority in all our considerations, so we have set our recommendations. I again thank my colleagues and in particular Senator Giles for the very great effort and satisfactory result in producing this report. I am looking forward to what we will discover in tackling the private hospitals to produce the second half of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes and one of the senators who signed a dissenting report, I want to say a few words today about this report. I thank Senator Shirley Walters who was the first Chairman of the Committee for the work that she did while she was Chairman and, of course, Senator Giles for the work that she has done during the past few years. I would say that there will be another report in regard to private hospitals, which will probably be just as voluminous as this report on private nursing homes. So there will be plenty for people to read.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the dissenting report, I want to speak about the number of nursing home beds. I sometimes think that we fail to take into consideration the aging population in Australia. That is very obvious when one travels around. Recently I had the opportunity to visit Sinnamon Retirement Village in Brisbane, which is a very big place. It is not exactly a nursing home; I suppose it is really a hostel care facility. There are many elderly people in the Retirement Village. There were many people aged over 80 or 90 in the hostel section who have not been placed in the nursing home section. A large number of people in our population these days are living longer. I feel that it is very important and necessary that enough provision should be made for nursing home care.

Of course, in my opinion tender loving care is as important as the nursing care. I suppose many people who reach the stage of being placed in a nursing home do not realise where they are. I feel that the loving care of the nurses is very important. I am quite sure that if families are not satisfied with the care that their parents are getting in a nursing home they will take some action to try to find a home in which the quality of care is better. I certainly do not think that the Government's proposal to reduce the number of nursing home beds is a very good idea.

I have talked about the care of the patients. With regard to the ownership of nursing homes, I cannot see any reason why doctors should not be able to own nursing homes and why, if they want to, they cannot send their patients to those homes. I cannot quite understand the thinking in that regard. My attitude is this: Who will provide the finance for nursing homes? I am sure that in many cases the doctors would not find the nursing homes to be financially beneficial. That is another reason why we put in a dissenting report about the ownership of nursing homes. These are some of the matters that we felt very strongly about and which we wanted to bring before the Senate.

I want to make my views known about these matters to explain why I signed the dissenting reports. I thank the staff who worked on the report. They have had a very big job. Their job, of course, is not yet complete because we must still bring forward the report on the remaining section of the inquiry. The care of the elderly is a very important subject in many ways. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go over the large area of agreement contained in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. It is, as Senator Giles has already said, a very comprehensive report. We took a long time to complete our inquiry into one section of the terms of reference that were given to us. The other section concerns hospitals. The nursing home section having now been completed, I, along with other members of the Committee, would like to thank the staff for all of the hard work. I congratulate Senator Giles for her excellent chairmanship of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, by far the majority of the recommendations had the full agreement of the Committee. There were four areas with which I disagreed and about which I presented minority reports. I think it would be appropriate if I referred to those areas. The first is in regard to Chapter 1 of the report which concerns what we should do about the number of nursing home beds. I believe, along with other members of the Committee, that there is a very large number of alternative services that can be given to the elderly prior to their entering nursing homes. Those alternatives would perhaps alleviate the necessity for their having to undergo nursing home care. There is a tremendous area. I do not believe that we have touched on it in full detail. I think it is very dangerous to come down with a specific number for nursing home beds. As I pointed out in the minority report, the policy of coming up with the maximum number of beds could be rendered inappropriate when governments take such action as they have just recently taken in regard to the 35-day rule. That practice could render any figure that we cared to set now inappropriate in the future. Governments take action and I do not believe we can come down with a hard and fast rule.

That issue concerns the first of my dissenting reports. The second concerns fee setting. There has been, as we know, a tremendous problem with fee setting. The High Court of Australia has been involved time and again with the Department of Health in this area. Indeed, the Department chose to ignore the High Court's and other courts' decisions on many occasions. We had a thorough debate as to whether good will should be considered part of the value of a nursing home when it is bought. I believe that that is automatic. Good will is always part of any business. It does not matter what business one is buying; goodwill is part of the price. If the price is to be included in the fee structure, of course good will must be included. One cannot just say: 'It is a bit expensive for government to include it; therefore we will knock it out'. That is exactly what a majority of members of the Committee said: 'It is a bit too expensive for the government to include good will in the price, so we will just knock it out'. Good will is part and parcel of any profit made by the seller, and it is certainly a cost to the buyer. I believe that is another area of very justifiable concern outlined in the minority report.

I come now to the subject of ownership of private nursing homes. As honourable senators know, the Committee has suggested that prior to the sale of a private nursing home the owner should notify the Government of quite a number of matters. I would regard that as a complete invasion of privacy. The Committee recommended:

That proprietors of private enterprise nursing homes intending to sell their nursing home be required to notify the Commonwealth Department of Health of this intent and that such notification be made not less than 30 days before the sale.
Under the recommendation proprietors would be required to inform the Department on quite a number of matters, one of which is:
. . . an audited profit and loss account of the business and, if relevant, any actual or intending bankruptcy, insolvency and receivership proceedings.

In other words, proprietors would have to tell the Department their private business and would have to make sure that they did so before a sale went through. I believe that this would be ludicrous invasion into private business and I do not go along with it. The excuse for the Committee making this recommendation was that a subsidy of $365m a year is paid to patients in private nursing homes; without this subsidy private nursing homes would be unable to keep their doors open; because private nursing homes, through their patients, receive this form of subsidy all details of ownership must be disclosed. The recommendation requires that a nursing home display its ownership details in its foyer and that the public know everything.

Mr President, as you might well imagine, other industries receive far greater subsidies than does the nursing home industry. To prove that I need only point to the Budget Papers of last year which stated that the Commonwealth Government would pay out an estimated $1,053m in direct subsidies to industry. That is just the tip of the iceberg. There are other heavily subsidised industries. The Industries Assistance Commission report on passenger motor vehicle components states that in 1980, some time ago in financial terms, passenger vehicle purchasers-that is, the man in the street-paid about $1,000m to support the passenger vehicle industry. I repeat: $1,000m was paid by the man in the street to support the motor vehicle industry. It is not suggested that the names of all the company owners that get some sort of subsidy from the Government by way of tariffs and other such protection and all their details be displayed. Therefore, I believe that to pick on the nursing homes is discriminatory and unnecessary.

I will now touch on the subject of doctors' ownership of private nursing homes. A recommendation has been made that doctors be not entitled to own private nursing homes to which they refer patients. Professor Opit came before the Committee to give evidence. I believe Professor Opit was completely irresponsible in the presentation of his evidence. He outlined all sorts of situations in which, he claimed, doctors were abusing the system. He gave us unsubstantiated evidence. When I asked whether he could substantiate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I seek your ruling. Professor Opit came before the Committee in the same way as did all other witnesses and gave evidence under oath. For the sake of the Committee's credibility I think I should bring that to your attention and request that Senator Walters not make such imputations on his integrity.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Walters is entitled to discuss the contents of the report and the evidence given before the Committee.

—Thank you very much, Mr President. As I said, Professor Opit came before us and gave unsubstantiated evidence. I asked him whether he had any proof to support the evidence he was giving us. He said no. He did not claim that the evidence he gave us was substantiated. He said that he did not have anything to prove what he was saying. He said that it was up to us to establish proof. It was only because he made that submission to the Committee that the Committee did what Senator Giles said it did and conducted such thorough research on the ownership of both private hospitals and nursing homes. As Senator Giles has already pointed out, the evidence we received from even a private search that had to be done was to the effect that doctors did not indulge in all the underhand business that Professor Opit had suggested. We discovered that, indeed, 88 doctors had financial interests in nursing homes throughout Australia and that the majority of such homes were interstate, well out of the doctors' areas of practise. The doctors had a financial interest in the medical field about which they had knowledge. Only six doctors had referred patients to their own nursing homes. No evidence at all was put to the Committee that those six doctors had done anything wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Professor Opit did a great service to the Committee, not in the way he expected but because we were able to investigate this matter thoroughly and we came up with no evidence at all to substantiate all those very nasty claims that he made. I was very pleased that we went as far as we did in researching this matter. That case underlines how dangerous it can be for a committee to refer to unsubstantiated evidence. As I have just told honourable senators, Professor Opit made all sorts of claims that were never substantiated, no matter how deeply we searched. I believe he was quite irresponsible in making those claims.

I come now to further unsubstantiated evidence that the majority of the Committee insisted on putting in the report. If honourable senators compare that evidence with Professor Opit's submission to the Committee perhaps it will show clearly why I objected to it. The Committee was referred to two phone-ins on the problems in nursing homes. I think there were 610 calls, two of which were substantiated. I understand that it is very difficult to substantiate complaints made on phone-ins, but in Western Australia an effort was made to substantiate the complaints and only two of them were substantiated. No attempt was made in New South Wales. That the Committee, in its report put down all of the complaints and reiterated the most emotive of them, even though they were completely unsubstantiated, and used them as evidence of bad nursing home care was, I believe, completely irresponsible and was just headline-grabbing by that Committee.

I was very critical of the Committee for including unsubstantiated evidence, in the report, and consequently I made a minority report in this area. A number of photographs to which reference has been made in this debate were included in the report. Photographs of patients 1 and 2 showed bedsores that were most unattractive and emotional, and those photographs were printed in the report in colour. The nursing home involving those patients had already been closed by order before the report came down. As for patient 3, the home had already changed hands and is now of a very high standard. Patient 4 came from an area that was altogether outside the Committee's terms of reference.

Before I became a member of this place I was a nurse and am well aware of how unattractive bedsores look and how difficult they are to nurse. It was never said at any stage that the Committee also had evidence that patients were brought from public hospitals into nursing homes with similarly horrific bedsores. The whole emphasis was to the effect that this occurred only in private nursing homes. This is certainly not a fact. Public nursing homes also have this problem. It is a most unfortunate area, and I believe that given today's new technology, with the additional facilities that are available, such cases should be few and far between. Those photographs were put in the report even though the committee has visited many nursing homes in Australia and found few badly run; they were in the minority. Indeed it was not just a minority, because 49 per cent could be regarded as a minority-it was a vast minority, a very small number of nursing homes that were very badly run. We saw some of those homes, but as to the homes in which photographs were taken, two had closed, one had changed hands, and one was outside the Committee's terms of reference. I believe those photographs were included for emotive reasons only and by way of headline grabbing, which does a great disservice to the Senate.

On the question whether doctors should own nursing homes, which touches on the final minority report I brought in, I do not think Senator Crowley understood Senator Peter Baume's interjection when he said that it is a moral issue. Of course it is a moral issue. There are bad and good in every walk of life. If a doctor wants to own a nursing home and wants to own a private hospital and abuse the system by moving patients between the private hospital and the private nursing home, do honourable senators believe that legislation to the effect that a doctor is not allowed to own a nursing home will stop him? Of course it will not. One cannot legislate for that sort of moral matter. The doctor concerned will put up a nominee but he will still have the financial interest and will carry on in that way. There are good and bad in every profession and in every walk of life. One can never legislate to cover those areas. It is completely unwarranted and unnecessary to try to bring down a recommendation that doctors not be permitted to own private nursing homes to which they can send patients when the Committee has had no substantiated evidence and has been into that area very thoroughly. The Committee is only half way through its terms of reference. It has ahead of it the private hospitals in Australia, and I look forward to serving on the Committee in that area. The Committee has worked very well. There are only one or two small areas in which there is disagreement, and I emphasise that by far the majority of the recommendations had the full agreement of the entire Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate, but I want to pick up a couple of points that have not been mentioned by other speakers. I also wish to reply briefly to a number of points made by Senator Walters. I, too, was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, but came into its deliberations late, as did other members who were appointed to the Committee after the double dissolution. Unfortunately, I did not have the benefit of visiting the nursing homes involved in the inquiry, although in the course of my work I have visited other nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention the reactions that I have experienced to the report since it was tabled. Due to printing difficulties, the report is not yet in print. That is unfortunate because I have found a big demand in the community among people who are interested in reading the report. However, members of the Committee were supplied with a few copies of the report which we have been able to lend out to interested individuals and organisations. I have found a great deal of interest in the community, particularly from organisations concerned with care of the aged, and in general very wide support for the recommendations of that report. Incidentally, I have found among those who have read the report no objections whatever to the inclusion of the photographs. In fact, the position is quite the reverse, especially from organisations concerned with the level of care offered in nursing homes.

What has not been mentioned so far in this debate is the number of young people who are in nursing homes. It is not generally recognised, unless people have friends or relatives in such a position, that a growing number of young people-in some cases as young as the late teens and in their twenties-reside or 'live' or 'are patients in' in nursing homes, often as a result of motor car accidents, diving accidents and so on, but also as a result of slow degenerative illnesses. I should like it put on record that the Committee and its report did not neglect the needs of those residents. The report refers in one of its recommendations to the fact that nursing homes specifically set up for young people should be funded separately from other nursing homes and that they might more appropriately be put in the handicapped persons assistance program. It was also recommended that when young people are in nursing homes with a mix of ages, special provision should be made for those young people, whose needs are quite different from those of the frail aged.

In the limited amount of time that is left to me before the adjournment of the debate, I wish to mention one other positive aspect of the report before I come to a couple of criticisms of Senator Walters's remarks. A good deal has been said in this debate about nursing homes, but I would stress that the Committee also gave attention to alternatives to nursing homes, some of which were mentioned by Senator Walters in her remarks, such as domiciliary care. That is an aspect of which the Committee is mindful and would like to see taken up in some detail pehaps, not by the present Committee but by another more appropriate committee or elsewhere. Such a committee could consider not only the subject of domiciliary care and the level of community support to the elderly who wish and are able to remain in their own homes with some community support, but also the provision of help such as an effective, low cost alarm system, which is often all that is needed for elderly persons to stay in their own homes so that they can get help if necessary.

Returning to a couple of points that Senator Walters made, she seems to see it as objectionable that notification of ownership should be displayed in nursing homes and available to people who are to be admitted to nursing homes. It is not just a question of the subsidy, but I think any government subsidy implies a responsibility on the part of the people receiving it. I know that in theory that subsidy goes to the patient, but in fact it is paid to the nursing home. It also implies accountability to the taxpayers, the people who are supplying that subsidy. More importantly, it is about a responsibility to residents and their relatives, who have a right to know who owns that nursing home and who may then, if they wish, exercise a different choice if an alternative is available and they do not wish to be admitted, in light of the information on ownership. We have in Victoria similar legislation to what is proposed and it does not seem to create any problems.

The parallel was drawn with other industries. Many of us would like to see other industries which have been heavily subsidised in the past made more accountable from the taxpayers' point of view. However, we are not talking about other industries at the moment; we are talking about nursing homes. Senator Walters mentioned that there was little evidence of doctors indulging in underhand business and that the report showed that only 88 doctors were actually registered as owners. But as Senator Giles has pointed out, we were not able to find out who were the real owners behind the large numbers of students and housewives who appear on the records of ownership. I know a lot of students and housewives and none of them could, of their own account, own large pieces of real estate or large businesses, as many of those nursing homes are. Even with company title searches it was not possible to find out who were the real owners behind what I might call shadow owners-I will not go so far as to call them puppets-but I think, without knowing who those owners are, we could hazard a pretty good guess as to who many of them would be.

I think it was unfortunate that those remarks were made about Professor Opit, who has a very high standing among the organisations that I have been consulting with since this report came down as a very credible witness. We have had recent arguments in this place about degrees of proof, and I think this is another case where an unreasonable degree of proof is being asked for. Finally, I am very glad that this report has been brought down. I look forward to the second half being brought down later this year. I hope that the report will be generally available to the public very shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also indicate for the record that the substance of that communication has been confirmed orally to Australian diplomatic representatives in Paris and we have had cabled advice of that confirmation. As to the larger questions lying behind Senator Robertson's question, it is the Government's belief, as was stated yesterday by the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, that the proposed shipment to the French company and to France is what may be described as a commercial ruse designed to encourage a refusal by the Australian Government of an export approval for this shipment, given our well-known policy in relation to uranium intended for end use in France. I am confident, as the Minister for Resources and Energy responsible for this, that the safeguards system which continues to operate in relation to France pursuant to bilateral agreements both with France and Euratom will ensure that, even if the present contract amount of uranium is delivered to France in the first instance, it will not in fact be used there.
